featured.title: John Summit and Dimension Deliver High-Energy Remix of ‘Silence’
featured.description: John Summit releases his ‘Silence’ remix with drum-and-bass staple, Dimension, through Tomorrowland Music. The Delerium rework has been one of the most requested IDs of the year after appearing at Ultra Europe, Red Rocks Amphitheater, and major festival sets across Summit’s massive global run. The track brings new life to a classic record that has
featured.fullContent:
John Summit releases his ‘Silence’ remix with drum-and-bass staple, Dimension, through Tomorrowland Music. The Delerium rework has been one of the most requested IDs of the year after appearing at Ultra Europe, Red Rocks Amphitheater, and major festival sets across Summit’s massive global run. The track brings new life to a classic record that has already shaped decades of electronic music culture.

‘Silence’ Remix – John Summit, Dimension

The remix opens with Sarah McLachlan’s familiar vocals, paired with a repeating synth that adds D&B tension. The rework’s atmosphere forms as her dopamine-ripping chorus returns. As the build forms, the chorus becomes chopped and stuttered to push the energy higher. The pinnacle of energy launches into a powerful Dimension drop driven by rapid drums and a full low end. Euphoric John Summit synths arrive near the end, blending his melodic edge with Dimension’s familiar production.

The break resets the mood and brings Sarah back into focus, letting the original lyrics breathe. Another build forms with tight percussion and ear candy textures. The final drop hits with a mix of Summit’s club-ready power and Dimension’s unmistakable drum-and-bass intensity. The result is a polished, high-impact rework that carries the emotion of the original while delivering the John Summit we all love.

The Artist

John Summit is a Chicago-born DJ and producer popular for energetic sets and charting dance releases. His rapid rise includes performances at Lollapalooza Paris, Austin City Limits Festival, London’s O2 Arena, and countless more. His style blends house, techno, dubstep, and whatever he wants, really.


Dimension is a London artist recognized for his signature approach to drum-and-bass. He has headlined the 2024 WORSHIP tour, played Ultra Miami, performed at EDC Las Vegas, and has performed at other world-renowned festivals for years. His crisp production and high-speed sound make him a defining figure in the genre.

The post John Summit and Dimension Deliver High-Energy Remix of ‘Silence’ appeared first on EDMTunes.

featured.title: Dancing Astronaut’s New Music Friday: GENESI & Rivo, ALLEYCVT & Level Up, Clüb De Combat, DREYA V, Gorgon City and more (November 14 – 21, 2025)
featured.description: New music highlights from Dancing Astronaut’s Artists to Watch in 2025 Clüb De Combat – Lé Fire Clüb De Combat return with “Lé Fire,” their explosive debut on Three Six Zero Recordings. Named a Dancing Astronaut Artist to Watch in 2025, the duo continue their rapid rise with standout releases on Defected, Diynamic and DJ support from Solomun, Peggy
featured.fullContent:
New music highlights from Dancing Astronaut’s Artists to Watch in 2025

Clüb De Combat – Lé Fire

Clüb De Combat return with “Lé Fire,” their explosive debut on Three Six Zero Recordings. Named a Dancing Astronaut Artist to Watch in 2025, the duo continue their rapid rise with standout releases on Defected, Diynamic and DJ support from Solomun, Peggy Gou, and CamelPhat. Their breakout year includes sold-out headline shows in New York and Los Angeles and major appearances across Pacha Ibiza, Space Miami, and Radius Chicago. – Alex Lambeau

DREYA V & Sian – 93

Fresh off her set at EDC Orlando, DREYA V teams up with Sian for “93,” a track paying homage to the warehouse rave era of the ’90s — “reimagined with a sleek, futuristic bite,” as the two shared on Instagram. She also teased that her EDC set was recorded, featuring unreleased music including her standout remix of The Killers. – Zach Salafia

ALLEYCVT & Level Up – BELIEVE

Two of the hottest names in bass music collide on “BELIEVE,” a massive collaboration that sees ALLEYCVT and Level Up seamlessly combine their production styles. The two recently appeared on stage together at EDC Orlando to play the track out together – a highlight moment from the festival. ALLEYCVT recently announced her biggest tour yet — the ‘9 Lives Tour‘ spanning 22 dates from January to March in 2026. – Zach Salafia

GENESI, Rivo & Aya Anne – Karma

Two Dancing Astronaut Artists to Watch in 2025 on a singular title is a surefire recipe for success. GENESI and Rivo have already proven their respective standings this year, and now they’ve come together for a long-awaited joint effort. “Karma” — featuring vocals from GENESI’s longtime collaborator Aya Anne — effortlessly blends both artists’ styles, resulting in an undeniable house weapon that has remained one of the most sought-after IDs in their sets this past year. – Ross Goldenberg

Buka – Hot 2 Deff [EP]

Buka makes a powerful EP debut on Solomun’s Diynamic imprint with Hot 2 Deff, with a title track that’s already become one of the most in-demand house IDs of the year. What started as a mystery cut in Solomun’s Pacha Ibiza sets, ‘Hot 2 Deff’ quickly received support from CamelPhat, Innellea, Max Styler and countless others before its official release. Backed by the b-side “One Touch,” the two-track release showcases rhythm and emotion, cementing Buka’s status as a name to watch. – Alex Lambeau

Kaskade – I Can’t Make You Love Me (feat. Cayson Renshaw)

Kaskade teams up with rising indie-folk/alternative artist Cayson Renshaw for a reinterpretation of Bonnie Raitt’s classic “I Can’t Make You Love Me.” Built around Renshaw’s raw, heartfelt delivery of the iconic line “Cause I can’t make you love me if you don’t,” the track starts as a slow, emotional ballad before Kaskade lifts the track into his signature, melodic drop. This modern spin, which blends indie storytelling with intense emotional production, arrives ahead of Kaskade’s upcoming album, undux, out December 4. –Liana Stern

Gorgon City – Mitsubishi (feat. Muki)

Gorgon City return to their Realm Records imprint with “Mitsubishi,” featuring vocals from Muki. For over a decade, the UK duo have remained pillars of the house scene, consistently delivering records that ignite dance floors. Following recent standout releases — including their remix of L.P. Rhythm’s “Versatile” and their massive John Summit collaboration “Is Everybody Having Fun” — “Mitsubishi” keeps their momentum soaring and proves once again why they remain essential listening. – Danielle Carty

TOBEHONEST – Fallin / Danger

TOBEHONEST is ushering in a bold new chapter with his “Fallin / Danger” release, showcasing his evolving sound and creative range. The project features a standout collaboration with Broken Hill on “Danger,” adding an extra layer of intensity to the EP. After making waves on Black Book with his debut release “Maquina De Bailar,” TOBEHONEST now pushes further with a project that blends fearless production and fresh energy – signaling a big leap forward for his artistry. – Danielle Carty

Wax Motif – BOTA (feat. MC Lan)

Wax Motif taps into Brazilian funk energy on his new single “BOTA,” teaming up with powerhouse vocalist MC Lan. The track is built on sharp percussion, call-and-response vocals, and an infectious rhythm tha’s engineered for the dancefloor. “BOTA” showcases Wax Motif’s effortless ability to move between cultures and club scenes, while maintaining his signature sound. – Liana Stern

Lane 8 & Arctic Lake – Say The Word (Sultan + Shepard Remix)

The one-year mark of Childish has somehow already come and gone, but Sultan + Shepard are helping stoke the flame of Lane 8’s fifth album with their newest remix offering. Originally debuted during the duo’s back-to-back set on the first day of the year at Proper NYD, Sultan + Shepard’s remix of “Say The Word” has finally answered the release pleas from countless This Never Happened fans, re-energizing Lane 8 and Arctic Lake’s original. – Ross Goldenberg

Featured image: Megan Burch

The post Dancing Astronaut’s New Music Friday: GENESI & Rivo, ALLEYCVT & Level Up, Clüb De Combat, DREYA V, Gorgon City and more (November 14 – 21, 2025) appeared first on Dancing Astronaut.

featured.title: Experts Only Festival Is Returning to NYC in 2026
featured.description: Following its explosive, sold-out debut, John Summit’s Experts Only Festival is officially returning to New York City on September 19–20, 2026. After drawing more than 50,000 fans in its inaugural year and making headlines across major media outlets, the festival is gearing up for an even bigger takeover of the city next fall. Experts Only […] The
featured.fullContent:
Following its explosive, sold-out debut, John Summit’s Experts Only Festival is officially returning to New York City on September 19–20, 2026. After drawing more than 50,000 fans in its inaugural year and making headlines across major media outlets, the festival is gearing up for an even bigger takeover of the city next fall.

Experts Only launched in 2025 at Randall’s Island and instantly became one of New York’s most talked-about dance music events. Rolling Stone, Forbes, the New York Post, and Dancing Astronaut all praised the festival for bringing major electronic energy back to NYC with coverage calling it:

“Huge success,” “a festival that reshapes NYC’s music landscape,” and “100 times yes.”

Now, John Summit and partners Medium Rare, Relentless Beats, and EMW are ready to push things furth

2025 Attendees Get First Access & Loyalty Presale Announced

To reward those who supported the festival from the beginning, 2025 ticket holders will receive exclusive first access to next year’s event. The Loyalty Presale begins: Tuesday, November 25 at 12pm EDT / 9am PDT. Tickets will be extremely limited and offered at the lowest tier.

If last year’s immediate sellout is any indication, these presale passes will be gone fast.

A Look Back at the 2025 Debut

The inaugural Experts Only Festival delivered two unforgettable days featuring a massive blend of dance music’s biggest names and community driven energy that felt truly Summit-coded.

2025 highlights included:

  • Two headline sets from John Summit
  • Kaskade b2b Cassian
  • Green Velvet b2b Layton Giordani
  • LP Giobbi
  • Kasablanca
  • DJ Seinfeld
  • Pete Tong
  • Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs (TEED)
    • more surprise moments and rising talent across house, techno, and melodic worlds

The excitement didn’t stop there; the multi-stage setup, massive crowds, and all-night energy made it clear that Experts Only wasn’t just a first-year success. It was a statement.

What to Expect for 2026

Organizers confirm that the 2026 edition will expand its footprint, elevate its production, and continue growing the event’s dedicated community. While the full lineup is still under wraps, fans can expect more high-profile debuts, b2bs, and John Summit-curated surprises.

More details, including the complete 2026 lineup, will be revealed over the coming months. But if you were at the 2025 edition, you already know Summit doesn’t play when it comes to production, scale, or energy.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Experts Only Festival (@expertsonlyfest)

The post Experts Only Festival Is Returning to NYC in 2026 appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.title: VELD 2026 Returns With Spectacular Lineup To Downsview Park
items.description: Can you believe we’re already talking summer festival season? As Toronto braces for winter, we’ve got something to look forward to—VELD’s 2026 lineup is here! From July 31 to August 2, Downsview Park will host Canada’s biggest EDM festival, and it’s back for its 13th edition, bigger and better than ever. This year’s lineup brings […] The post VELD
items.fullContent:
Can you believe we’re already talking summer festival season? As Toronto braces for winter, we’ve got something to look forward to—VELD’s 2026 lineup is here! From July 31 to August 2, Downsview Park will host Canada’s biggest EDM festival, and it’s back for its 13th edition, bigger and better than ever. This year’s lineup brings a massive mix of electronic genres, so bass lovers and techno fans are in for a treat. Check out the full lineup below and start planning those summer vibes now.

Veld 2026 LineUp

Earlier this year than usual, VELD teased fans midweek with a stacked Phase 1 Mainstage lineup. It featured Above & Beyond, Armin van Buuren, Fisher, Illenium, Kx5, and Mau P. Deadmau5 returns to his own festival with Kaskade as Kx5 for the first time. Above & Beyond make their comeback after a successful Bigger Than All Of Us tour, while Illenium returns to the Mainstage following his 2023 set. Trance icon Armin van Buuren also rejoins the roster after last appearing in 2022. Just yesterday, Ink Entertainment dropped the full Phase 1 lineup, adding techno powerhouses Charlotte de Witte and Sara Landry to the mix.

VELD 2026 goes beyond the Mainstage with a lineup that spans the full electronic spectrum. Expect pounding techno from Lilly Palmer and Miss Monique, alongside bass-heavy chaos from Subtronics, Ray Volpe, and Level Up. SLANDER and Black Tiger Sex Machine bring melodic and aggressive bass, while James Hype and Galantis deliver house grooves and feel-good anthems. With Mau P and FISHER driving tech-house energy and Charlotte de Witte commanding the underground, this year’s festival promises a dynamic experience for fans of trance, house, techno, and bass alike. With so many big names in this lineup, we are hoping there are going to be 4 stages this year , excited to see how Downsview Park will transform for the 2026 Veld edition.

Join VELD and Ink Entertainment’s Instagram contest, open until November 26. Check out their latest post for full details:

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Veld Music Festival (@veldmusicfestival)

Sign up for presale on the official Veld website. Stay tuned to EDMTunes for all your 2026 festival lineups.

The post VELD 2026 Returns With Spectacular Lineup To Downsview Park appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.description: The hottest bass music trio, Levity, released their explosive new single “Can’t Get Enough” today via Ultra Records. The track delivers Levity’s trademark high-octane energy, blending thunderous basslines with euphoric melodies and massive festival drops that showcase the group’s signature sound. LISTEN HERE The new single arrives as Levity embark
items.fullContent:
The hottest bass music trio, Levity, released their explosive new single “Can’t Get Enough” today via Ultra Records. The track delivers Levity’s trademark high-octane energy, blending thunderous basslines with euphoric melodies and massive festival drops that showcase the group’s signature sound.

LISTEN HERE

The new single arrives as Levity embark on their headline Lasership Tour, which opened with two sold-out nights at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. The tour will continue through Denver, New York City, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago and more. The trio are also confirmed to perform at Ultra Music Festival Miami and Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival next year, cementing their status as one of the most in-demand acts in electronic music.

Beyond the stage, Levity are using their platform to make a difference. The trio have partnered with End Overdose, a nonprofit organization that will host information tables at select tour stops to promote safer and more supportive live music spaces. Levity are also donating a portion of tour proceeds to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, underscoring their ongoing commitment to mental health awareness and community impact.

“Can’t Get Enough” is available now on all major streaming platforms via Ultra Records.

The post Levity Ignite Their Next Chapter With New Single “Can’t Get Enough” via Ultra Records appeared first on FindYourSounds.

items.fullContent:
AIAIAI opened its Black Friday sale with a wide range of solid price drops across its headphones and portable monitors.

The sale runs from November 20 through December 1 and feels like one of the more practical chances this year to update a setup without overspending. AIAIAI tends to hold its pricing pretty steady throughout the year, so when these windows open up, they matter.

Producers, DJs, and anyone building out a mobile workflow will find real value across the catalog.

The Biggest Discounts Worth Paying Attention To

The UNIT 4 monitor system moves from 799 to 649 for the pair. Anyone who works in small spaces already knows how rare it is to find portable speakers that translate well. The UNIT 4 sits in that category where you can trust what you are hearing without fighting the size of the box. At this price, it is one of the standout items of the entire sale period.

This year also marks the first time AIAIAI dropped the price on the TMA 2 DJ Wireless and the TMA 2 Studio Wireless. These two models tend to appeal to different corners of the community. The DJ Wireless version is built to take a beating and still feel comfortable through long sets.

The Studio Wireless version leans toward production and editing where reliability and clarity usually matter more than isolation. Seeing both discounted for the first time adds a good amount of weight to the sale.

Lower-priced models like the TMA 2 Move XE, TMA 2 Move, and the Tracks versions also received healthy cuts. These land in that entry point sweet spot where you can use them daily, toss them in a bag, and not worry about damaging something expensive. For friends and family buying holiday gifts for people in music, these are the models that will probably move fastest.

A Good Time to Build Out a Modular Headphone System

One of the reasons AIAIAI continues to be popular is the modular design of the TMA 2 line.

It makes parts easy to swap, upgrade, or reconfigure without buying a full new system. Black Friday creates a smart moment to pick up new drivers, headbands, or pads and shape a setup around the way you work. If you want to move from DJ work to production, or from production to travel, you can adapt the system without starting over.

The main thing to keep in mind is that stock usually shifts quickly once holiday shopping starts. UNIT 4 monitors, the DJ Wireless model, and the Studio Wireless model are often the first to disappear, so grabbing those earlier in the sale is the safer move.

items.title: How It Was Made: T & Sugah, Grace Barton – “The Speaker”
items.description: T & Sugah are closing out a huge year with a track that hits with purpose. “The Speaker” pushed their sound into new territory while holding onto the high-energy club presence that has turned their sets into reliable highlights across festivals and tours. Grace Barton’s vocal brings lift and presence, and the way it sits [...] Read More... from How
items.fullContent:
T & Sugah are closing out a huge year with a track that hits with purpose. “The Speaker” pushed their sound into new territory while holding onto the high-energy club presence that has turned their sets into reliable highlights across festivals and tours. Grace Barton’s vocal brings lift and presence, and the way it sits inside the arrangement gives the whole track a clear identity from the first line to the final drop.

This edition of the How It Was Made series walks through the exact tools behind that energy. The trio opened their project and explained the synths, plugins, and processing chains that shaped each section. Their approach is built on intention and repetition, leaning into clean design choices that support the vocal while keeping the drop as heavy as it needs to be.

If you have been following their recent releases on Monstercat, you can hear how their technique keeps developing with each project. The choices in this breakdown reflect the same mindset they bring to their live sets, focusing on sound quality, clarity, and weight. Everything here comes straight from the artists, word for word, so you can see precisely how “The Speaker” came together.

Serum 2

You probably heard of this one, but Serum 2 is our go to plugin. For those who don’t know it yet; it’s an incredibly intuitive and versatile synth that does most kinds of synthesis and sampling. If you want you could even use it as kind of a DAW and build a tune in one instance of Serum 2.

Going through this project we realized that Serum 2 is in fact the only VSTi we used. The main lead (see screenshot) is the most characteristic sound we made with it for this tune. As you can see, we combined some basic waveforms playing higher harmonics on top of a sub. We then run it through a resonant flange filter to accentuate the screechy harmonics even more. In the FX section we use a lot of clipping and distortion, this is what really creates the character of the sound.

If you want to make this type of sound filters like “flg” and “cmb” in Serum are fun to experiment with since they accentuate certain harmonics. Then in the FX section the “diode 1” distortion often gives it the right edge. If you want to use reverb, another great feature in Serum 2 is that you can sidechain the internal reverb with an envelope.         

ENDLESS SMILE

Another plugin we use in every project is Endless Smile by Dada Life. It’s an automatic buildup plugin with just one knob and 7 presets that range from a gentle filter + reverb build to very extreme ones with all sorts of pitch and phaser effects. In general, it’s great for making buildups that used to take a lot of time to make in a quick way.

We mostly use it for its amazing reverb though. In the first preset called “fists in the air” you can use the know to slightly high pass and reverb a certain element, which gives it a very clean washed out feeling. So, on some background and pad sounds we keep it halfway on permanently. Apart from that we use it to wash out the lead bass at the end of each for bars, to make it hit harder again when the new 4 bars part starts.

In any EDM genre you can just use this plugin as a one knob reverb, like we do. I think the main difference with other reverbs is that in Endless Smile the low end gets cut as you add more reverb, which prevents the reverb from making your mix muddy. My tip is to use it in a more static way on background sounds and in a more dynamic way, with lots of automation, on lead sounds.

StandardCLIP

This one gets used on almost every channel, it’s called StandardCLIP by SIR Audio Tools. It does exacly what the name suggests, it’s just a very simple clipping plugin that does exactly what it should do without any bells and whistles. I really like the simple yet effective visual feedback that the plugin provides so you know how hard you’re hitting the ceiling.

For The Speaker the most apparent use is on the lead synth. When you make these kinds of rough synth sounds, clipping them really brings out the power. The lead synth in The Speaker we clipped so hard that you couldn’t even see it on the visualizer anymore (I think it’s around 12 dB of clipping). On top of that we used the softflipping setting at 80%, this brings up the quiet parts of a sound even more.

When you use StandardCLIP, or any other distortion plugin, it’s important to keep the sound clean. Between every stage of clipping and distorting we have an EQ or Soothe2 to clean up some of the muddiness and to make sure that the right frequencies are hitting the distortion. In general it can for example be nice to cut some low mids and turn up the mids before clipping, it’s something you have to experiment with though.

Soothe2

This brings us to the final plugin we want to talk about which is Soothe2 by Oeksound. It’s a plugin that’s used to clean up your sounds, or even multiple sounds when you use it on a bus. Soothe2 basically automatically finds nasty resonances and turns them down. You can adjust the range of frequencies it affects as well with the EQ.

We used it a lot for The Speaker as well, and again its most important use was on the lead synth. We did multiple stages of clipping, EQing and distorting, but after that the sound ended up a little harsh. We just put soothe2 on there with it’s default setting and turned up the depth a bit to taste. It made a huge difference to the sound of the lead, which would have been very exhausting to listen to otherwise.

From our experience there are two main uses for Soothe. One of them is just for general clean up, like we did with our lead synth. The other one is to clean up specific areas. In a vocal for example you can sometimes find annoying peaks and resonances in the low mids. You can then isolate that specific range with the EQ in Soothe2 and let it work its magic in that area. A bonus use case it to use it as a sidechain plugin, by for example using the vocal as sidechain input, making it dip for example the instrumental at the exact frequencies where the vocal is hitting.

Quick Tips On Making Music

Tip #1: Clip and Dip; Do multiple rounds of distorting/clipping a sound and cleaning them up with an EQ, until it sounds fat.

Tip #2: Don’t be afraid to use samples and presets; a lot of big producers do. Creating a sick tune should be priority 1, making everything from scratch is fun, but not the most important part of making music.

Tip #3: Less is More. The cliche holds up haha. As we progressed, we noticed that our tunes have fewer and fewer elements. It’s better to have one good lead, then to layer 5 mediocre leads.

Tip #4 : Take breaks and change playback environment. Leaving a tune for a day and coming back or playing it in the car, in the club, in the living room can give you a lot of info. Not even because of the different sound system, but to see if it conveys the feeling you want it to convey in those settings.

Tip #5: Work with others. First of all, it’s inspiring and gives you input you wouldn’t get normally. Secondly, it’s a great way to learn new production techniques.

The post How It Was Made: T & Sugah, Grace Barton – “The Speaker” appeared first on Magnetic Magazine.

items.title: Zomboy Ignites Bassrush Records With New Single ‘Doomsday’
items.description: Zomboy returns with ‘Doomsday,’ his long-awaited debut on Bassrush Records and the fresh new set piece for Apocalypse: Zombieland 2025. The track arrives after months of global road-testing and lands as one of his heaviest weapons yet. Built for chaotic festival moments, it captures the raw intensity that has defined his music for more than […] The
items.fullContent:
Zomboy returns with ‘Doomsday,’ his long-awaited debut on Bassrush Records and the fresh new set piece for Apocalypse: Zombieland 2025. The track arrives after months of global road-testing and lands as one of his heaviest weapons yet. Built for chaotic festival moments, it captures the raw intensity that has defined his music for more than a decade. The release also marks a milestone for Insomniac‘s Bassrush, matching one of dubstep’s most explosive artists with its flagship event.

‘Doomsday’

‘Doomsday’ starts with an eerie ambience and an early radio announcement broadcast that sets the D-Day tone. A raging build forms instantly, pulling listeners toward the edge of existence. The ominous radio voice returns with the phrase “he is alive,” launching the track into a sharp, relentless climb. The tension snaps into a synth fake-out, then spikes again towards a classic Zomboy drop.

The first drop hits with massive bass design, OG dubstep horns, rewinds, and jagged synth phrasing that cuts through the mix. It breaks only long enough to reset the tension. Another build forms, holding pressure without losing momentum, and drops into a second, heavy section that functions as a breakdown drop. After a brief atmospheric breath, the final build teases a possible hardstyle shift. Instead, Zomboy stays true to his roots and detonates a final dubstep drop shaped in the style of the first. The result is a weapon designed with precision for peak-festival energy.

Zomboy

Born in Pendeen, Cornwall, Zomboy rose from rock and metal beginnings before shifting into electronic production. His early demos caught the attention of Never Say Die founder SKisM, which launched a rapid ascent that led to sets at Ministry of Sound, EDC Las Vegas, Red Rocks, and sold-out venues worldwide. His catalog includes classics like ‘Organ Donor,’ ‘Game Time,’ ‘Terror Squad,’ and ‘Like A Bitch,’ which helped define dubstep’s sharp, cinematic edge.

Now steering his Dead Man Walking imprint while maintaining a global touring presence, Zomboy continues to deliver music with precision, intent, and a dark theatricality that fans instantly recognize. His approach favors quality over quantity, often leaving space for production between releases to maintain the craftsmanship behind his sound.

The post Zomboy Ignites Bassrush Records With New Single ‘Doomsday’ appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.title: Rod Brito releases new EP ‘Waves Like This’ via Red Room
items.description: Brazil’s Rod Brito returns to his Red Room label with the ‘Waves Like This’ EP 21st November 2025. He follows up last Summer’s remake of the iconic ‘Mas Que Nada’, which won support from Gorgon City, Diamond Dealer, Sam Divine, Jess Bays, and more, with the title track of his ‘Waves Like This’ EP opening with refined flow and distinctive vocal text
items.fullContent:
Brazil’s Rod Brito returns to his Red Room label with the ‘Waves Like This’ EP 21st November 2025. He follows up last Summer’s remake of the iconic ‘Mas Que Nada’, which won support from Gorgon City, Diamond Dealer, Sam Divine, Jess Bays, and more, with the title track of his ‘Waves Like This’ EP opening with refined flow and distinctive vocal textures, gliding eﬀortlessly between groove and atmosphere. ‘Thunder’ ups the intensity with a deeper, progressive drive. It’s a journey charged with rhythm, energy, and emotion. Closing with ‘Collapse’, Brito blends melodic shades of house and techno into a hypnotic, timeless finale designed for late-night storytellers.

A staple of the electronic music scene since the ’90s, Red Room founder Rod Brito continues to evolve his sound through emotive, dancefloor-focused productions. With a career spanning appearances at Burning Man, Piknic Électronik, and releases on Mobilee, Ritter Butzke, and Super Feet, he once again demonstrates his mastery of mood and movement, crafting a versatile collection that bridges emotion, precision, and pure groove.

Rod Brito ‘Waves Like This’ releases 21st November 2025

Tracklist
01 Waves Like This
02 Thunder
03 Collapse

items.title: LEON releases new EP ‘Parallel Lines’ via LOCUS.
items.description: A consistent presence across the global house landscape for over a decade, LEON has built a reputation on his instinctive feel for the dance floor. From long-standing residencies at Marco Carola’s Music On Ibiza and Italy’s iconic Cocoricò, to appearances alongside the likes of Carl Cox, Jamie Jones, Loco Dice, and The Martinez Brothers, he’s becom
items.fullContent:
A consistent presence across the global house landscape for over a decade, LEON has built a reputation on his instinctive feel for the dance floor. From long-standing residencies at Marco Carola’s Music On Ibiza and Italy’s iconic Cocoricò, to appearances alongside the likes of Carl Cox, Jamie Jones, Loco Dice, and The Martinez Brothers, he’s become a trusted name for quality, energy, and longevity. As a producer, his releases on standout labels such as Cocoon, 8bit, Hot Creations, and Crosstown Rebels have kept his sound front and centre in the sets of leading selectors worldwide. Following a prolific run of releases throughout 2025, his debut on LOCUS arrives as a natural next step, bringing his sleek, club-driven sound to one of the scene’s most loved floor-focused imprints.

Title track ‘Parallel Lines’ opens with rolling low-end, rowdy low-ends and crisp percussion, unfolding into a simmering trip that balances tension and motion in equal measure. ‘Vibe Nation’ keeps the heat firing. loaded with zipping energy, tight drum work, and more no-nonsense UKG-fueled basslines that push and pull effortlessly, while closing cut ‘One Two Three’ delivers one final late-hours weapon, veering into hypnotic territory for a smooth yet driving finale that perfectly encapsulates LEON’s diverse and timeless touch.

LEON ‘Parallel Lines’ EP lands on 21st November 2025 via LOCUS.

2) Vibe Nation
3) One Two Three

items.title: ALTO releases new EP ‘Everybody’ via Trick
items.description: Well-informed by a deep love of crate digging, ALTO mixes up minimal and tech on labels like Adrianza Records, Kaluki Musik, and Resonance Records. With strong support from top-tier tastemakers including Marco Carola, Michael Bibi, and Franky Rizardo, the London-based talent continues a standout year with an impressive debut outing on Patrick Toppi
items.fullContent:
Well-informed by a deep love of crate digging, ALTO mixes up minimal and tech on labels like Adrianza Records, Kaluki Musik, and Resonance Records. With strong support from top-tier tastemakers including Marco Carola, Michael Bibi, and Franky Rizardo, the London-based talent continues a standout year with an impressive debut outing on Patrick Topping‘s trend-setting Trick.

“Proud to drop ‘Everybody’ on Trick, which started as a loop at home one late summer night but really captured that
groove, movement, and signature party energy that comes with my unique sound”. – ALTO.

The EP opens with the irresistibly dubby tech rhythms of ‘Everybody’ Rolling drums and feathery hi-hats merge with a teasing female vocal to build tension, before dropping into whimsical, trippy synth motifs. ‘Handle It’ follows with a hooky, pitched-up R&B sample layered over tight, well-programmed drums, dusty textures, and punchy bass. Rounding out the release, ‘Watch Me’ delivers an intoxicating mix of prying synths, weighty kicks, and crisp percussion. Clever vocal layers and catchy melodic details ensure it lingers long after the drop.

ALTO ‘Everybody’ EP drops via Trick on 21st November 2025.

  Tracklist:
1. Everybody
2. Handle It
3. Watch Me

Instagram – Soundcloud – Facebook – Spotify

items.title: Pope Arranges Padre Guilherme To Play DJ Set For Archbishop’s Birthday
items.description: A massive electronic music event held outside St. Elizabeth Cathedral in Košice, Slovakia, has sparked discussion after receiving the official endorsement of Pope Leo XIV. The party, held on Saturday, November 8, 2025, was led by Padre Guilherme Peixoto, a Catholic priest who also works as a professional DJ. The event, which featured Dance music, [
items.fullContent:
A massive electronic music event held outside St. Elizabeth Cathedral in Košice, Slovakia, has sparked discussion after receiving the official endorsement of Pope Leo XIV. The party, held on Saturday, November 8, 2025, was led by Padre Guilherme Peixoto, a Catholic priest who also works as a professional DJ.

The event, which featured Dance music, lasers, and projection mapping, was held to celebrate the 75th birthday of Archbishop Bernard Bober. The association between faith and rave culture generated instant controversy, with supporters praising the Church’s modern approach to connecting with youth, while critics denounced the fusion as sacrilege.

The connection to the Vatican was cemented when a video greeting from Pope Leo XIV was played on a large LED screen behind the DJ booth. The Pope, known for his progressive stance, expressed joy and called on the young people gathered to be “witnesses of communion, builders of bridges, and sowers of trust“. The recorded message is also used as part of Padre Guilherme’s original single, ‘Dear Young People’.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Catholic Connect 🇻🇦 Vatican (@catholicconnect)

Ultimately, while the Pope did not personally attend, his public blessing of the event has made the unconventional celebration a widely discussed moment in both religious and electronic music news.

The post Pope Arranges Padre Guilherme To Play DJ Set For Archbishop’s Birthday appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.title: Stay hydrated, stay secure: a guide to festival-ready hydration and fanny packs
items.description: Between marathon sets, strict security checks, and packed crowds, the right bag can make or break your experience. Having gear that balances style, comfort, and security is crucial. Here’s what every festivalgoer should know before stepping through the gates. Hydration Packs: The All-Day EssentialA hydration pack isn’t just for storage, it’s surviv
items.fullContent:
Between marathon sets, strict security checks, and packed crowds, the right bag can make or break your experience. Having gear that balances style, comfort, and security is crucial. Here’s what every festivalgoer should know before stepping through the gates.

Hydration Packs: The All-Day Essential
A hydration pack isn’t just for storage, it’s survival gear for long days and late nights. The best festival backpacks keep your water cold, your valuables protected, and your shoulders comfortable. Look for at least a 2 liter hydration capacity, insulation, anti-theft compartments that rest against your back, and padded straps for comfort. RaveRunner has a number of hydration packs that stand out for combining both functionality and design, making them one of the go-to sources for seasoned attendees.

What to look for in a hydration pack:

  • Anti-theft design: The safest packs keep the main compartment against your back, making it nearly impossible for anyone to access while you’re dancing.
  • Hydration capacity: At minimum, you should look for a two-liter hydration pack so you can stay hydrated without constant refills that keep you off the dance floor.
  • Insulated or cooler-lined compartments so your drinks stay refreshing even after hours in the sun.
  • All-day comfort: Padded straps, breathable materials, and balanced weight are non-negotiable when you’re wearing it from gates to afters.
  • Festival-ready features: Bonus details like chest strap pockets give you a secure but easy-to-reach spot for valuables.

Hydration Fanny Packs: Compact, Secure, and Versatile
For instant access to your essentials on the dance floor, the hydration fanny pack is the perfect companion. They keep critical items like your phone, ID, and keys securely zipped against your body without weighing you down. Prioritize durable materials, tight zippers, and adjustable straps that can be worn crossbody or around the waist. RaveRunner’s hydration fanny packs deliver the comfort, flexibility, and anti-theft features you need for a worry-free night.

What to look for in a hydration fanny pack:

  • Durable materials that won’t rip or tear if someone tries to force their way in.
  • Secure zippers or buckles that stay closed even when you’re in the middle of the crowd.
  • Room for hydration: space to stash a water bottle or soft flask can make a big difference.
  • Comfy & Outfit-friendly: Find a pack that matches any look and is versatile enough to wear crossbody, around the waist, or slung over the shoulder.

Clear Bags: Staying Festival-Compliant
Clear bag policies are now the standard at most major festivals, but that doesn’t mean you have to sacrifice utility. Look for transparent bags that meet policy sizing, include hidden pockets, and maintain comfort. RaveRunner’s clear fanny packs and clear hydration backpacks let you breeze through the entrance, offering peace of mind and keeping you gate-ready.

What to look for in a clear festival bag:

  • Policy-approved sizing so you don’t get turned away at the gate.
  • Anti-theft details like hidden pockets and secure buckles, because clear doesn’t mean unprotected.
  • Comfort and versatility—the best designs let you wear them crossbody, as a sling, or around the waist without bouncing around.
  • Hydration-ready options for anyone who wants the benefit of a bladder system without sacrificing compliance.

Choosing What’s Right for You
Whether you need the capacity of a hydration pack, the quick access of a fanny pack, or a clear bag to meet gate compliance, choosing the right gear is crucial for a stress-free experience. Festival-ready bags keep your essentials secure, your hands free, and your focus on the music. Here’s some tips to help you decide what is right for you:

  1. How much do you carry?
    • If you bring layers, merch, or snacks, a festival hydration pack has you covered.
    • If you prefer essentials only, go for a hydration fanny pack.
  2. Do you need clear compliance?
    • Check the policy before you leave. A clear fanny pack or clear hydration backpack ensures you won’t be turned away at the entrance.
  3. What’s your comfort style?
    • Modular packs let you adjust—crossbody, waist, or sling—so you can dance without feeling restricted.

Featured image: RaveRunner

The post Stay hydrated, stay secure: a guide to festival-ready hydration and fanny packs appeared first on Dancing Astronaut.

items.title: Igloofest Montreal announces 2026 season lineup, expands into new Canadian city
items.description: Canada’s coldest festival is back — and bigger than ever. Igloofest has unveiled the full lineup for its flagship Montréal event, alongside the return of its Gatineau and Québec City editions, and the debut of a brand-new stop in Edmonton. Montréal’s 2026 edition will once again transform the city’s historic Old Port into a frozen... Read More ▸ Th
items.fullContent:
Canada’s coldest festival is back — and bigger than ever. Igloofest has unveiled the full lineup for its flagship Montréal event, alongside the return of its Gatineau and Québec City editions, and the debut of a brand-new stop in Edmonton.

Montréal’s 2026 edition will once again transform the city’s historic Old Port into a frozen playground for electronic music lovers, running four weekends straight from January 15 – February 7. This year’s lineup is stacked with both international heavyweights and local favorites, delivering a fiery soundtrack for the frigid months ahead. The opening weekend brings house-heavy headliners Disco Lines, SOFI TUKKER, and The Blaze, setting the tone for another unforgettable season.

Each following weekend ups the ante with performances from DJ Snake, Madeon, Elderbrook, Skull Machine — an explosive new bass project from Black Tiger Sex Machine and Kai Wachi – Max Styler, and a rare back-to-back set from techno queens, Nicole Moudaber and Montréal’s own Misstress Barbara.

Of course, Igloofest wouldn’t be Igloofest without showcasing the city’s thriving local scene. Collectives like Ferias and Homegrown Harvest return for stage takeovers, bringing the underground energy that defines Montréal’s dance music culture.

Once Montréal wraps, the Igloofest tour heads across the country — touching down in Gatineau (February 12–14), Québec City (March 6–8), and making its first-ever appearance in Edmonton from March 13–15.

Pre-sale registration opens November 6 at 11 a.m. ET, with general on-sale to follow November 7 via Igloofest’s official website.

Featured image: Alexis Monet

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Igloofest Montréal (@igloofest_mtl)

items.title: Alex Atenciano collab with Mellizos ‘Get Lit’ EP on Hottrax
items.description: Keeping its global focus front and centre, Jamie Jones’ Hottrax continues to serve up the good by introducing a fresh collaboration between Texas-based duo Mellizos and Spanish talent Alex Atenciano. Together, the trio unite to deliver ‘Get Lit’, a slick, groove-driven three-tracker that captures the label’s instinct for championing distinctive sou
items.fullContent:
Keeping its global focus front and centre, Jamie Jones’ Hottrax continues to serve up the good by introducing a fresh collaboration between Texas-based duo Mellizos and Spanish talent Alex Atenciano. Together, the trio unite to deliver ‘Get Lit’, a slick, groove-driven three-tracker that captures the label’s instinct for championing distinctive sounds made for the dancefloor.

Based in Texas, twin brothers Mellizos have a sound rooted in tight percussion and rolling basslines, earning early nods of support from the likes of Marco Carola, Franky Rizardo, and The Martinez Brothers. They join forces here with Madrid’s Alex Atenciano, one of Spain’s promising new voices, whose vibrant productions have found a home on labels such as Be One Records and Happy Techno Music, with support from Marco Carola, Chelina Manuhutu, and SOSA. 

“This is one of the most dreamt-of releases of my career. Our inspiration has always been house music that makes you want to move the moment you hear it. When I got together with my friends, Mellizos, and we decided to collaborate on these tracks, the three of us had a clear vision: music that you could feel deep in your body and soul. We worked very quickly and knew from the outset that what we had created deserved to be among the greatest, and today we can confirm that we have achieved that.” – Alex Atenciano.

“We really wanted to make something unique and standout, something that would get attention and be remembered. Every track in the EP has its own story, like when ‘Sabor De Noche’ got played by PAWSA, it was the first breakthrough we had and a sign that we found a sound that was truly ours.” – Mellizos.

Opening with ‘Get Lit’, the title cut locks into a rolling rhythm from the start, rich chords with crisp percussion and infectious vocalsnippets. ‘Chatter’ keeps the energy levels simmering, driving momentum through tight drum programming and an elastic groove, before ‘Sabor De Noche’ closes the package with funky riffs, warm sonics, and playful energy perfect for notable moments. Showcasing two acts united by a shared feel for rhythm, the EP captures the collaborative spirit at the heart of Hottrax, a label consistently shining a light on emerging artists making a mark within the international club landscape.

Mellizos & Alex Atenciano ‘Get Lit’ EP drops via Hottrax on 21st November 2025.

items.title: Love to be… Reveals Lineup For Sheffield Festival 2026
items.description: Sheffield’s legendary house music brand, Love to be… is set to stage a return of its all-day hometown festival on Sunday 24 May 2026 to a new location at SteelYard in Kelham Island. The change marks an exciting new chapter for the Love to be… Inner City Festival as the team moves from beloved mainstay […] The post Love to be… Reveals Lineup For She
items.fullContent:
Sheffield’s legendary house music brand, Love to be… is set to stage a return of its all-day hometown festival on Sunday 24 May 2026 to a new location at SteelYard in Kelham Island. The change marks an exciting new chapter for the Love to be… Inner City Festival as the team moves from beloved mainstay FORGE to Sheffield’s vibrant container park for its biggest city edition yet.

From the original house music pioneers to today’s most in-demand selectors – including Sheffield’s finest – the 2026 lineup is a celebration of house music that will keep multigenerational crowds on their feet, long after the sun goes down.

The 2026 headliners include global house music stars Roger Sanchez, David Penn, Low Steppa, The Shapeshifters, Trimtone and Carly Wilford. Joining are UK mainstays Grant Nelson, Groove Assassin, Jon Pleased Wimmin, Allister Whitehead, Tom Wainwright and Love to be… co-founder Tony Walker. Residents and local Sheffield talents are well represented with the likes of Cheryl Wright, Dino, James Worrall, Joshua Brooks, Keexx, Shaun Hayes, Sinclair, Stuart Pilling, Watty and more, completing the bill.

House music lovers can expect a full-scale takeover of SteelYard when Love to be… takes up residence. The space will be transformed into a purpose-built festival site over four stages, with massive sound systems, immersive light production, street food traders, outdoor bars and a bustling VIP area.

“Love to Be… Inner City Festival at Steelyard Sheffield is a celebration of music. Our vision for this event is to bring together generations of house music lovers in one of Sheffield’s most iconic industrial spaces, transforming it into a vibrant hub of energy, unity, and creativity. The move has seen us able to create new stages and increase capacity and deliver Sheffield an event to be proud of. It’s about honouring Sheffield’s rich musical heritage while pushing forward with new sounds, diverse artists, and immersive experiences that reflect the heartbeat of the city.” – Marc Dennis (Director of Love)

Known for its distinctive open-air layout, SteelYard Kelham has become a go-to destination for quality dance music events, staging such legendary names as Graeme Park, to the contemporary day rave Groovebox x Bounded Festival with Rossi., Micah Baxter and LP Rhythm.

Love to be… first launched in 1994 at The Music Factory on London Road and quickly became known as the North’s original superclub. Thirty years on, the brand is stronger than ever, hosting sell-out festivals and events across Harrogate, Ibiza, New York and Sydney, broadcasting via its global syndicated radio show, and releasing handpicked sounds across its cutting-edge labels.

EVENT INFO
Love to be…Inner City Day Fest
Sunday 24 May 2026
SteelYard Kelham
Unit 4, The Yard, Bardwell Rd, Neepsend, Sheffield S3 8AS
12pm – 11pm
Tickets from £37+ bf via https://www.skiddle.com/e/41353357

The post Love to be… Reveals Lineup For Sheffield Festival 2026 appeared first on The Nocturnal Times.

items.title: What to Expect at the Insomniac Performer Auditions
items.description: On Saturday, March 28, in Downtown Los Angeles, Insomniac will hold its 5th annual Entertainer Audition at Exchange. As a tryout for the bold who hope to one day stoke the audience from onstage, within the crowd, and all throughout the festival footprint, the audition is one of the most memorable dance culture experiences of […]
items.fullContent:
On Saturday, March 28, in Downtown Los Angeles, Insomniac will hold its 5th annual Entertainer Audition at Exchange. As a tryout for the bold who hope to one day stoke the audience from onstage, within the crowd, and all throughout the festival footprint, the audition is one of the most memorable dance culture experiences of our time. To some performers, it’s a reunion for the family they’ve created together. To others, it’s a chance to chase their dreams of glory on an Insomniac stage. Ultimately, the audition experience is one of our most asked-about and inspiring events throughout the year, because it offers a deeper glimpse into a life of professional performance for any soul brave enough to contemplate a career onstage.

If you’re one of the many thinking about auditioning, but you’re on the fence—wondering “What’s the experience of it actually like?” or “How do I know it’s for me?”—then we’ve got just the spotlight to put on the situation!

To learn all this and more, we sat down with the casting queen behind the scenes, MsEasy. From her vantage point as Entertainment Director, Easy oversees everything that has anything to do with entertainers at Insomniac events. From costumes to styling to management and more, she’s at the start, the finish, and every step in between. So, we rounded up the Qs she gets the most. Read on, and see what she had to say!

What’s it like to be in the family of Insomniac performers?
Inspiring. I think it’s a community that really bonds over their mutual interest in performing and sharing their performance with Headliners or with the crowd in general, wherever they may be. In the Insomniac performer family, we get to travel together, and I see a lot of the relationships turn into lifelong friendships. You see that the bond is really strong. It’s not just a job; it’s a lifestyle. It’s an actual community that I think really is open. We like to receive people. It seems like it’s really life-changing when people come fully into the circle.

What’s the process from application to the stage?
The true audition starts at 1pm, but around noon (or even earlier), people will start lining up to fill out performer applications. We ask that everyone bring portfolio pictures, like headshots, so they can be easily found later throughout the process. People ask if it’s necessary, but I think it makes you look professional, legitimate, and serious about your craft. The headshots don’t have to be on a professional level; it’s just something that represents you that you’ve put a little effort into.

They’re gonna drop off all their information, fill out their application, and they’ll get a number. They’ll be sent into the photographer room, where they’ll have their picture taken. Then they will go from there to the queue line for the actual audition. We’ll see 2–3 people at a time, and they’ll have the ability to go from one platform to the next, so it spans minutes—sometimes less. That’s the freestyle round.

People I want to see go into a second round, the choreography round, get a callback slip. I don’t need to see every kind of performer or every single dancer for the choreography round, and not everyone gets called back for it. Some people think that when they don’t get a callback for the choreography round that they’re out, which isn’t the case. There’s just another technical round that some people will get put into, and others won’t. Not make or break, but this is a part of it.

Some people will get callback slips. They will go into a choreography room, where choreographers will be teaching them their own sequence of dance, so nobody has to come with choreography, rehearsed material, or music. There will be a live DJ playing the entire time. More or less, you just show up as you, and you get put into different rounds.

They learn the choreography, and the teams will come back up in groups of 6–8 and perform. This round is also specific to, but not just pertaining to, kineticFIELD casting. Casting for kineticFIELD at EDC Las Vegas, the stage that travels the world, will be selected from this round.

If I’m already an Insomniac entertainer, do I have to show up and audition?
My answer is always YES. One, it’s good for us to be able to reassess people’s skills every single year. It’s like an update. I would like to be able to see if people improved. It’s a great time to showcase your talent and be seen for reevaluation every year. This also for me is a time where I really see people showing up for their team and their craft; it’s kinda like that quote: “80% of success is showing up.” I really believe that you show up for what you want, and the people that show up are the ones who get the casting. All of the positions for EDC Las Vegas itself will book from this audition.

I would also like to see a lot of different types of entertainers in the freestyle round. First of all, it is dance-based, but more that anything, I’m looking for stage presence. If you’re not particularly a dancer—or let’s say you want to be a mascot, or you’re an aerialist, or you’re any other kind of entertainer—I will see your stage presence when you audition. You don’t necessarily have to be a technical dancer, but show me the charisma or the ability or the energy or whatever it is you’re trying to put forth. You can always specify on your resume or your application what you focus on or what you’re applying for.

If I’m an aerialist, should I audition through the dance round?
We don’t have a rig to audition aerial at the venue, so I’m encouraging aerialist to still show up and be seen in person, because it’s the easiest way to get your foot in the door if you put yourself in front of a judge or casting director. Me seeing you in person gives me more of an idea of your ability and your energy and your presence. I like to see their faces in person. There is a specialty round for stilters, acrobats, and contortionists. A lot of these specialty acts we’ll do in a round after the freestyle round but before the choreography round.

I’m a stilter. Should I bring my stilts?
Yes. Go through the first round, and then stilt-up for the specialty round.

Are you auditioning all types of performers?
At the end of the day, all types of entertainers can audition. If they specify on their application, I will see that they aren’t necessarily applying for a dance role, but we don’t have any special equipment, like aerial rigs. We don’t allow flow props in the venue, so that means hoops or fire arts. Anything large that is spinning or handheld won’t be allowed. Those people can still apply by email application at mseasy@insomniac.com. However, I would like for hoopers to still audition through the dance line. That way, I can still see them. I have a lot of performers who do specialty hoop but end up doing other roles for us at the event. I like our entertainers to be multitalented and flexible, so they have the ability to fill more than one role. It never hurts if you’re an amazing hooper to come try out, because I may have something for you later.

What are newcomers most surprised by at the auditions?
I think they’re excited, because Insomniac events are so dynamic and magical. We have people fly in from all over the country. To be with hundreds of people and to feel that energy and excitement—this is one reason why I want to push people to audition, because it’s a great experience. One, it helps you assess where you’re at as an entertainer, and two, it will reaffirm your goals and desires as an entertainer. I have a lot of people come up to me afterward to say what an inspiring day it was for them. “This is pushing me to be a better entertainer, and I now realize where I need to improve.” There are a lot of benefits to auditioning.

Sometimes people are surprised to see that much talent and diversity and how many people there are all with the same hopes, wishes, and goals. In fact, a lot of entertainers say it’s one of the bigger auditions they’ve ever attended. Even though we’re a music festival company, we view entertainment as a key part of the experience.

What do I wear to an audition?
In the dance community, it’s common practice to wear fitted clothing. On the flyer, it does say low-rise dance shorts and crop tops for females. Heels, wedges or boots, hair and makeup, fitted clothing for men and women. If you’re really covering yourself up and I can’t see your silhouette or the way you move, it could hinder the outcome of your audition. Come in what is considered professional attire. Keep it simple; you don’t want to distract from your talent with your outfit. The only time that doesn’t apply is when your outfit is really part of your talent, and the only time that comes into play is when you’re a drag queen or some type of specialty performer that relies heavily on their outfit. So, you need to kind of assess what you want to be cast as and how that pertains to how you look.

What’s the easiest way for an audition to go wrong?
The number one thing I see that goes wrong is that people lose their confidence. I know it can be a lot of pressure leading up to the moment, but you have to believe in yourself and be comfortable while you’re auditioning, because it really shows. People really speed up, but I think in my mind, “Just slow it down; it’s going to be okay.” Another huge one is that people look down. I want to see what you have to offer to the crowd. I want you to connect. I want to feel what it is you’re trying to convey to our audience, and I’m your audience in that moment. If you’re looking down at the ground the entire time, you’re not smiling, or you’re going too fast, then you’re losing your chance.

This is a very positive place with an amazing community of people. You’ll see pros helping novice dancers. I love walking around and feeling that kind of energy and community that’s happening between strangers. Like, the old schoolers watching the new people come in and helping them and giving them pointers and working on choreo with them. It sounds cheesy, but it’s heartwarming because it reinforces the love I have for what we do. That’s one of things that makes Insomniac so different. It’s that vibe; it’s the heart that’s in it. Out of all the large-scale auditions out there, I feel that this is the most welcoming and least scary one.

What’s a piece of advice you’d pass on to someone asking about auditioning for the first time?
Try and try again. It’s the performer’s mantra. Also, if you’re gonna talk the talk, make sure you walk the walk. Back up what you want with skill. Go take classes and be serious about what you want to do, because it’ll show.

 

The Performer Auditions take place at 1pm on Saturday, March 28, at Exchange LA, located at 618 S. Spring Street in Downtown Los Angeles. Chosen performers will be contacted via email after the auditions, so please make sure to write legibly on your application and include an email address on your resume.

For all the latest on the auditions, follow MsEasy on Instagram, or keep in step with updates from the Entertainment Team by signing up to receive the entertainment newsletter.

items.title: Boys Noize Reimagines Human Resource ‘Dominator’
items.description: Human Resource’s rave classic ‘Dominator’ returns in explosive form as Boys Noize delivers a high-energy rework that revives one of electronic music’s most iconic hooks for a new era. Leaning into the track’s original Hoover synth and memorable vocals, the GRAMMY-winning producer transforms the 1991 anthem into a modern techno weapon built for peak
items.fullContent:
Human Resource’s rave classic ‘Dominator’ returns in explosive form as Boys Noize delivers a high-energy rework that revives one of electronic music’s most iconic hooks for a new era. Leaning into the track’s original Hoover synth and memorable vocals, the GRAMMY-winning producer transforms the 1991 anthem into a modern techno weapon built for peak-hour moments.

‘Dominator’ – Boys Noize Rework

The Boys Noize ‘Dominator’ rework opens with a pounding techno kick and flashing sirens that set a ready-to-dance tone. The original Human Resource vocal, “I want to kiss myself,” jumps in first, followed by the iconic line that shaped early hardcore. As the phrase “I am the one and only dominator” fires, the track charges into its first drop.

The drop carries the classic Boys Noize energy, filled with attention-grabbing synths, playful sound design, and gritty textures. More lines from the 1991 anthem return during the break, including “I’m bigger, I’m bolder, I’m rougher, I’m tougher,” adding a familiar punch before the next surge. The second drop hits harder than the first, powered by a shuttering rhythm that moves with percision. A final drop lands with similar mind-wraping energy, capped by a signature sound design that twists the groove into a wild, club-ready spin.

Some background on ‘Dominator’ by Human Resource

The original ‘Dominator’ became a global rave staple in 1991, reaching #6 on the Dutch Top 40 and #36 on the U.K. Singles Chart. Its signature Hoover synth helped define the early hardcore and gabber sound. This made Human Resource into one of the first Dutch dance acts to break internationally. The Boys Noize ‘Dominator’ rework acts as a modern bridge. It pushes a rave classic into a new era without losing its core identity.

Boys Noize

Boys Noize, the project of Berlin-based artist Alex Ridha, has built a global reputation on banger tracks, memorable performances, and fearless sound design. Also, as a GRAMMY-winning producer, DJ, he blends techno, electro, house, and experimental edges with a forward-thinking approach. This mindset and career has shaped those genres and inspired rising artists. His work spans festival stages, underground rooms, film scores, and fashion collaborations.

Overall, Ridha’s catalog includes productions for artist like A$AP Rocky and Frank Ocean. Also, countless remixes, some of which were for Daft Punk and Depeche Mode. Continuing, his massive catalog of club hits such as ‘Mvinline’ and ‘Fine Day Anthem’. Through all these releases, he keeps one mission at the center: make music built for the dance floor and the fans who fuel it.


The post Boys Noize Reimagines Human Resource ‘Dominator’ appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.title: Tiësto Enters New Era With Album Announcement And First Single ‘Bring Me To Life’

The single arrives after he mysteriously went dark on social media, triggering a viral countdown and wave of […] T
items.fullContent:
The Single Will Be Debuted Live During Highly Anticipated Performance at Dreamstate SoCal This Saturday

Tiësto ignites a powerful new era with the release of ‘Bring Me To Life‘, a high-energy anthem featuring stunning vocals from FORS. The single arrives after he mysteriously went dark on social media, triggering a viral countdown and wave of global speculation among dance music fans and media. Listen HERE. 

Inspired by the overwhelming response to the euphoric and melodic moments from his PRISMATIC show this past June in Mexico City and beyond, Tiësto embarks on a bold new chapter inspired by where it all began. Tiësto to headline Egypt’s Great Pyramids of Giza concert on December 19th, where fans will experience this new sound in his 3-hour PRISMATIC DJ Set. 

‘Bring Me To Life’ captures the sweeping melodies, emotional lift, and atmospheric power that defined Tiësto’s early identity – now reimagined with modern production and a refreshed creative spark. The track draws direct inspiration from the massive fan energy erupting throughout Tiësto’s recent live shows as he revisited these foundational sounds at his live shows.

This weekend, fans will get their first live taste of what’s ahead as Tiësto brings his new sound to Dreamstate SoCal 2025, but this is just the beginning of much more to come.

Listen/Stream here.

items.title: RL Grime And Deadcrow Unite For Explosive New Rework ‘Dominator’
items.description: RL Grime teams up with rising artist, Deadcrow, to rework the Human Resource classic ‘Dominator‘ into a heavy dubstep and techno blend. The track arrives with major anticipation as both artists are two key figures changing the modern bass scene. Released on Armada Music, the label adds the record to its new wave of dance […] The post RL Grime And D
items.fullContent:
RL Grime teams up with rising artist, Deadcrow, to rework the Human Resource classic ‘Dominator‘ into a heavy dubstep and techno blend. The track arrives with major anticipation as both artists are two key figures changing the modern bass scene. Released on Armada Music, the label adds the record to its new wave of dance music.

‘Dominator’

The song opens with the original rebellious vocal that delivers the line “I am the one and only dominator.” The OG Human Resource synths and new drums follow and set a hard-hitting dubstep tone. The energy rises with layered percussion that builds toward a classic fake-out moment. The tension snaps into a fast-paced drop filled with crisp movement and detailed sound design. The second half of the drop leans into sustained bass hits that shake the mix.

The rework then shifts into war-like horns that create a dramatic pause. A melodic soundscape builds above them and widens the world of the song. The momentum returns as the elements rise together once again. Another fake out arrives to surprise listeners and flips the energy into a techno-heavy drop that still carries RL Grime’s signature dubstep feel. This rework of ‘Dominator’ takes genre-blending and new production styles to a whole new level.

The Artist Behind The ‘Dominator’ Rework

RL Grime

RL Grime came to fame in New York as a teenager with viral remixes of ‘Love Sosa‘ by Chief Keef and ‘Mercy‘ by Kanye West. His one-of-a-kind visual identity and annual Halloween mix series set him apart in the early trap era. His debut album, VOID, became number one on the Electronic chart in the United States and held the spot for a month. He followed with high-profile collaborations with Big Sean, Miguel, and Skrillex. He continues to tour the world and headline major festivals like Coachella and Lollapalooza.

Deadcrow

Deadcrow is a rising artist in the dance scene who has caught the attention of major producers like RL Grime, Zeds Dead, and more. His work blends cyberpunk themes with high energy and heavy sound design. His music carries influence from JDM culture, classic racing games, and the Blade Runner films. He tours worldwide and is now one of the first wave artists to tour the United States. His releases appear on major labels like Sable Valley, Deadbeats, Dim Mak, and others. His style is inspiring big and new artists alike and continues to push dance music forward.

The Original Artist: Human Resource

Human Resource is a Dutch electronic group from the Ridderkerk area. The early lineup included mixer Robert Mahu, keyboardist Johan van Beek, Jasper Drexhage, Guido Pernet, and rapper Larenzo Nash. The group earned worldwide attention in 1991 with their breakout single ‘Dominator’, the rave classic known for one of the earliest uses of the Hoover synth and a famous remix by Joey Beltram. After several lineup changes through the mid-90s, the group disbanded near the end of the decade. Guido Pernet later revived Human Resource with a new lineup in the 2000s, leading to renewed touring and the launch of the Dominator Festival in 2005, which remains one of the biggest events in hardcore and gabber music.

The post RL Grime And Deadcrow Unite For Explosive New Rework ‘Dominator’ appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.title: Oliver Heldens Reimagines Modjo’s Iconic ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)’ For A New Generation
items.description: Oliver Heldens revisits one of dance music’s most enduring classics with his rework of ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)’, out November 21 on Heldeep Records Originally released in 2000 by the French house duo Modjo, ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)‘ became a defining track of its era, blending house, funk, and pop in a way that transcended […] The post Oliver Helden
items.fullContent:
Oliver Heldens revisits one of dance music’s most enduring classics with his rework of ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)’, out November 21 on Heldeep Records

Originally released in 2000 by the French house duo Modjo, ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)‘ became a defining track of its era, blending house, funk, and pop in a way that transcended genres and generations. Now, more than two decades later, Heldens breathes new life into the classic, staying true to its unmistakable groove while elevating it with his signature precision and modern production touch.

Heldens’ rework has already received strong live support from Calvin Harris and Carl Cox, both of whom have featured it in their recent sets – a testament to the track’s crossover appeal across the dance music spectrum. The reimagining captures the warmth and nostalgia of the original while recharging it for today’s global dancefloors. 

The release arrives during a landmark year for Heldens, who recently celebrated 10 Years of Heldeep Records with a sold-out Amsterdam Dance Event showcase alongside Tchami, Don Diablo, Chocolate Puma, and Lee Foss. With “Lady (Hear Me Tonight)”, he continues to bridge eras and sounds, reaffirming his reputation as one of electronic music’s most innovative and enduring talents.

Oliver Heldens – ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)’ is available November 21 on Heldeep Records.

The post Oliver Heldens Reimagines Modjo’s Iconic ‘Lady (Hear Me Tonight)’ For A New Generation appeared first on EDMTunes.

items.title: Enrico Sangiuliano Teams with Vito Gatto for ‘Order In Chaos’ EP
items.description: Techno visionary Enrico Sangiuliano is set to unleash the penultimate release in his legendary label countdown, NINETOZERO. The new five-track EP, ‘Order In Chaos,’ sees the Italian maestro team up with acclaimed violinist and composer Vito Gatto for a stunning sonic triptych that defies traditional techno boundaries. Out Today, the release is cent
items.fullContent:
Techno visionary Enrico Sangiuliano is set to unleash the penultimate release in his legendary label countdown, NINETOZERO. The new five-track EP, ‘Order In Chaos,’ sees the Italian maestro team up with acclaimed violinist and composer Vito Gatto for a stunning sonic triptych that defies traditional techno boundaries.

Out Today, the release is centered on the concept that “Chaos is fundamental for creating something powerful.” Sangiuliano and Gatto blend electronic, classical, and electro-acoustic elements to create a journey through three distinct phases: tension, release, and dissolution.

Thematic Breakdown of the EP

The EP is a masterclass in conceptual sound design:

  • ‘Adaptation for Strings and 909’ (Enrico Sangiuliano & Vito Gatto): The cinematic overture sets the tone, built on the raw intimacy of Gatto’s processed violin soaring over the unquantized, “out of grid” pulse of an iconic Roland 909 drum machine. This is disorder made beautiful.
  • ‘Order in Chaos (Reactive Mix)’ (Enrico Sangiuliano): The title track is pure, rolling techno fury. It serves as the “release” point, a hard-hitting weapon where a shape-shifting lead synth flirts with total breakdown before the thunderous kick restores the dance floor’s gravity.
  • ‘Dissolution’ (Enrico Sangiuliano & Vito Gatto): The closing track provides beatless surrender. Strings and drums slowly dissolve into a weightless drone, guiding the listener into a final, infinite space.

The Countdown Continues

‘Order In Chaos’ is release #1 in the monumental NINETOZERO project. The label is a time-bound endeavor that intentionally counts down to #0, challenging the idea of perpetual music and encouraging listeners to focus on the present. With just one chapter left, the final moment promises to be something “unexpected and brilliantly innovative” from Sangiuliano.

This groundbreaking release sets the stage for Sangiuliano’s highly anticipated all-night-long SOLO show at Nitsa in Barcelona on November 28th, where he will undoubtedly integrate the cinematic and chaotic soundscapes of this new EP. Tickets HERE!

The post Enrico Sangiuliano Teams with Vito Gatto for ‘Order In Chaos’ EP appeared first on EDMTunes.
